Argument Summary: Skkiru’s “beggar” performance is riddled with misconduct that would alert any prudent anthropologist to the artificiality of the primitive culture. Rather than preserve the ruse for Snaddra, his actions repeatedly flout its rules, deplete its resources, and provoke Terran suspicion.  

I. Use of Banned Technology Violates “Primitive” Tabus  
  1.1. Forbidden Land Transport  
    – “they took time to get the things, and they worked so well … he was at the Earth ship long before the official greeters” (background).  
    – The very fact that the Terrans later question “Why … only the beggar wears mudshoes?” (Raoul: “Why should I know … only the beggar …,” background) demonstrates that pontoons and mudshoes are anomalous even to them. A genuine savage would lack skill and daring to deploy wrecked air-car parts.  
    – His eagerness (“he still had the equipment … run down … get it”) betrays contempt for the primitive regime. If he were sincere, he would strictly observe the interdiction on self-levitation and air-cars.  

II. Self-Serving Consumption of Scarce Gifts Undermines Survival Strategy  
  2.1. Immediate Chocolate Ingestion  
    – Though Terrans present chocolate “to soften” him, “Chocolate was found only in the most expensive … now neither … so … he ate the candy then and there” (background).  
    – This depletes one of the society’s most precious imports, weakening Snaddra’s position. A committed agent would ration or redirect supplies to the underground city for long-term benefit, not bolster his individual comfort.  
    – His own reflection: “It would have been better to flicker out on their own than to descend to a subterfuge …” yet he hastens to use chocolate suggests self-interest.  

III. Open Display of Professional Pride and Impatience Contradicts Desperation  
  3.1. Sarcasm in Terran Language  
    – Skkiru mutters in Terran, “Ha, ha! … Retouched pictures …” (background).  
    – Natives “were not supposed to understand” Terran, yet he risks speaking it in their presence—“Certainly … we do understand” (most literate have “third language”). His jab at retouching is a spoiler alert. A faithful performer would refrain from commentary that jeopardizes rapport.  

  3.2. Repeated “Pooh, pooh, POOH,” “grumble,” and threats of “stern deprivation”  
    – He “sulkily” agrees “I’ll go … but I don’t have to like doing it” (background).  
    – True beggars would adopt any comportment to elicit sympathy. His refusal to suspend personal preferences reveals disloyalty to the common cause.  

IV. Provoking Terran Distrust and Delay of Rapport  
  4.1. Terran Hesitation  
    – Despite “rain dance” invitation, Terrans delay engagement: “We must not establish undue rapport … Don’t be so impatient!” (Cyril: “We’ll find out later”).  
    – Their own scientists suspect their hosts. Skkiru’s behavior is the trigger. A well-performed beggar would have smoothed their path, not stall them, shortening contact and diminishing funding/trade prospects.  

V. Debunker of Debater_B’s “Convincing Patriotism” Claims  
  5.1. Withholding Underground Knowledge Is Default, Not Sincerity  
    – All participants share motive to conceal cities. Skkiru’s mere silence is insufficient proof of loyalty; the Terrans’ repeated allusions to “Gloch” and “missionaries” show they know fieldwork tactics. Skkiru’s failure to correct them is passive, not active defense.  
  5.2. “Primitive” Justification of Pontoons Is Self-Serving Ruse  
    – Debater_B’s assertion that “any land transport is primitive” contradicts Terran reaction. If pontoons were acceptable, why does Cyril frown and Raoul question his footwear?  
  5.3. Claimed Long-Term Plan to “soften them up” Lacks Follow-Through  
    – Unlike missionaries, he does not record data, learn Terran language more fluently, or guide them to resources; instead, he mopes and contemplates suicide. True strategic patriot would actively seek prolongation of contact, not flirt with death.  

VI. Conclusion  
Skirru’s violations of the primitive code, his resource-wasting comfort seeking, his public contempt and muttering in Terran language, and the resulting hesitation among the Terrans themselves all evidence that he is not sustaining the illusion but undermining it. A competent native agent would strictly adhere to tabus, conceal all signs of advanced technology, conserve gifts for communal use, and ingratiate himself wholeheartedly. By contrast, Skkiru’s behavior shrieks sabotage. Therefore, the correct interpretation is that Skkiru undermined the role of beggar and jeopardized Snaddra’s plan.
